CLIDEsc

Documentation for the code

«  Getting data out of CLIDE   ::   Contents

Documentation for the code¶

clide.clidesc_Obs(conn, table, channels, stations, from_date, to_date)[source]¶

returns the given observations table for the requested stations, date range and columns depends on an open clidDB connection clideDB

Usage: table = clidesc_Obs(conn, “obs_subdaily”, channels, stations, from_date, to_date) Currently no parameter checking.

clide.clidesc_ObsDaily(conn, channels, stations, from_date, to_date)[source]¶

returns the daily observations table for the requested stations, date range and columns depends on an open clidDB connection clideDB

Usage: table = clidesc_ObsDaily(clideDB, channels, stations, from_date, to_date ) Currently no parameter checking.

clide.clidesc_ObsSubDaily(conn, channels, stations, from_date, to_date)[source]¶

Read channels for stations (stations) from the obs_subdaily table usage: table = clidesc_ObsSubDaily(clideDB, channels, stations, from_date, to_date )

clide.clidesc_close(base_path, conn)[source]¶

docstring for clides

clide.clidesc_getColumns(conn, table)[source]¶

Return the column names of a table

conn : the postgresql connection table : string

the table (e.g. ‘obs_daily’, ‘obs_subdaily’)
columns : Pandas.Series
A Pandas.Series containing the column names

columns = clidesc_getColumns(conn, ‘obs_subdaily’) columns = clidesc_getColumns(conn, ‘obs_daily’)

clide.clidesc_getStationsByCountry(conn, country)[source]¶

gets all the station details for all stations in a given country code (single or vector). It opens the connection, reads the stations table country must be a string, with country codes (if more than one) separated by ‘,’

clide.clidesc_open(base_path, database='clideDB', user='XXX', password='XXX', dbhost='localhost')[source]¶

OPEN the ClideDB database and the progress file

clide.clidesc_rain24h(conn, stations, from_date, to_date)[source]¶

Utility function to read the rain_24h channel from the obs_daily table

clide.clidesc_stations(conn, stations)[source]¶

gets all the station details for a station number It opens the connection, reads the stations table station_no is a string, with stations separated by ‘,’
